1 Cell Structure
and Organization
Learning Outcomes
At the end of this chapter, you should be able to • describe the structure of animal and plant cells with their various organelles;
• know the functions of the different parts of a microscope and how to determine the actual sizes of biological specimens; • discuss the processes of cell division and cellular specialization; and • distinguish among the levels of cellular organization.

第一章
细胞结构和组织
学习目标
本章结束时，学生应能够： • 描述动物和植物细胞及其各种细胞 器的结构； • 了解显微镜各组成部分的功能，以 及如何确定生物标本的实际尺寸； • 讨论细胞分裂和细胞特化的过程； 以及 • 区分细胞组织的层次。

The invention of the telescope accelerated the process of space exploration and led to some of the most important discoveries in astronomy. Similarly, the invention of the microscope opened up new domains in biology that were not accessible before. Microscopes helped demonstrate that living things are composed of small units called cells. Cells were first discovered and named by Robert Hooke in 1665. He noticed a similarity between the shapes of plant cells and cellula, the small rooms in which monks used to live, thus deriving this name. Hooke managed to see the cell walls of dead plant cells (cork) under the microscope. These dead plant cells were devoid of the nucleus and other organelles found in most living cells. The first A scientist observing a sample of cells under person to actually observe a living cell under a microscope was the microscope Anton van Leeuwenhoek, who observed the alga Spirogyra, in 1674. Then, in 1838, Theodor Schwann and Matthias Schleiden concluded, after discussing their studies on cells, that both plants and animals are made up of cells. Schwann published this conclusion in his book Microscopical Researches into the Accordance in the Structure and Growth of Animals and Plants, in 1839.
